# How to create a new environment for document-subgraph

The steps are best followed in order.

## Create and populate shared secrets in AWS secrets manager

This is done by adding them in `plos-secrets` terraform project for appropriate environment.
Eg: https://github.com/omfsvcshub/infrastructure/pull/655

After applying this project, copy over the value of secrets from an existing environment and adjust appropriately. Doing this is important before proceeding to next step.

## Create aurora db project for new environment

Each environment has a separate auroradb cluster. Copy over the cluster from an existing environment, adjust the values in files and make sure `environment_locals.tf` points to the right location (it's a symlink).
Eg: https://github.com/omfsvcshub/infrastructure/pull/655


Apply this project before proceeding to next step.

IMPORTANT: After the project is applied, a user needs to be created inside database to work with iam authentication. Check the readme at github.com/omfsvcshub/infrastructure/terraform/aws/modules/plos/aurora/README.md for details.

## Create document-subgraph terraform project 

Copy over the document-subgraph from an existing environment. Go through all the files, fix values for the new environment, make sure `environment_locals.tf` symlink points to the right location.
Apply.

Eg: https://github.com/omfsvcshub/infrastructure/pull/655

## Add the environment in github repository

Add the environment in omfplos/infrastructure/terraform/github/environments/locals.tf. Copy over the environment variables from existing environments, adjust for new one.

IMPORTANT: After applying, the APOLLO_KEY secret will be created in this github environment. Fetch the value of the secret from AWS secrets manager. The secret name is `domain-gateway-router`. A secret with this name exists in all the AWS accounts for different environments (dev, stg, prod).

Eg: https://github.com/omfplos/infrastructure/pull/145

## Add new environment as deployment target

Add the newly created environment as deploy target in github workflow.

https://github.com/omfplos/document-subgraph/pull/19

# How to Create a New Environment for document-subgraph

{panel:title=ğŸ“‹ Overview|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#4A90E2|titleBGColor=#E8F4FD}
This document outlines the step-by-step process for creating a new environment for document-subgraph. **Follow these steps in order** for successful deployment.
{panel}

---

## ğŸ” Step 1: Create and Populate Shared Secrets in AWS Secrets Manager

Configure secrets in the `plos-secrets` terraform project for your target environment.

**Reference Example:** [Infrastructure PR #655](https://github.com/omfsvcshub/infrastructure/pull/655)

{warning:title=âš ï¸ Critical Step}
After applying the terraform project, **copy secret values from an existing environment** and adjust appropriately. This must be completed before proceeding to the next step.
{warning}

---

## ğŸ—„ï¸ Step 2: Create Aurora DB Project for New Environment

Each environment requires a separate Aurora DB cluster.

**Process:**
1. Copy cluster configuration from an existing environment
2. Adjust values in configuration files
3. Ensure `environment_locals.tf` symlink points to the correct location
4. Apply the terraform project

**Reference Example:** [Infrastructure PR #655](https://github.com/omfsvcshub/infrastructure/pull/655)

{info:title=ğŸ”‘ Database User Creation Required}
After applying the project, create a database user for IAM authentication. 
**See:** `github.com/omfsvcshub/infrastructure/terraform/aws/modules/plos/aurora/README.md` for detailed instructions.
{info}

---

## ğŸ“Š Step 3: Create document-subgraph Terraform Project

Set up the document-subgraph infrastructure for the new environment.

**Process:**
1. Copy document-subgraph configuration from existing environment
2. Review and update all configuration files for the new environment
3. Verify `environment_locals.tf` symlink points to correct location
4. Apply terraform configuration

**Reference Example:** [Infrastructure PR #655](https://github.com/omfsvcshub/infrastructure/pull/655)

---

## ğŸ”§ Step 4: Add Environment in GitHub Repository

Configure the environment in GitHub repository settings.

**Process:**
1. Add environment configuration in `omfplos/infrastructure/terraform/github/environments/locals.tf`
2. Copy environment variables from existing environments
3. Adjust variables for the new environment

{warning:title=ğŸ” APOLLO_KEY Secret Configuration}
After applying terraform:
- The `APOLLO_KEY` secret will be automatically created in the GitHub environment
- **Manually fetch the secret value** from AWS Secrets Manager
- **Secret name:** `domain-gateway-router` (exists in all AWS accounts for different environments: dev, stg, prod)
{warning}

**Reference Example:** [Infrastructure PR #145](https://github.com/omfplos/infrastructure/pull/145)

---

## ğŸš€ Step 5: Add New Environment as Deployment Target

Enable deployment to the new environment via GitHub workflows.

**Process:**
- Add the newly created environment as a deployment target in the GitHub workflow configuration

**Reference Example:** [Document-subgraph PR #19](https://github.com/omfplos/document-subgraph/pull/19)

---

{tip:title=âœ… Success Checklist}
Before considering the environment setup complete, verify:
- [ ] All secrets are properly configured in AWS Secrets Manager
- [ ] Aurora DB cluster is running and database user is created
- [ ] document-subgraph terraform is successfully applied
- [ ] GitHub environment is configured with correct variables
- [ ] APOLLO_KEY secret is populated from AWS Secrets Manager
- [ ] Deployment workflow includes the new environment
{tip}
